## Slide 3

Women’s Apparel Retail Case Study

Moving a legacy print-heavy women’s fashion brand to a data-first digital approach for marketing

BEN ANDERSON

PRESENTATION

---

## Slide 4

Key issue 1: Due to close alignment between Analytics and Marketing, we could quickly generate metrics for business case.

Key issue 2: Executive team had a hyper-focus on ROAS and were unfamiliar with digital – I would need to educate.cate the team.

Key issue 4:  My team was limited in resources to take on a project of this size, so I knew I would need outside help.

Key issue 3:  The macro retail environment was mercurial, leading to my focus on sustainable growth.

Background:  A women’s retail company selling online, through catalogs, and in-store.  The company had undergone rapid expansion over the previous decade but remained a lagger in the digital marketing space.  There was strong alignment between Analytics and Marketing due to my shared leadership of both teams, but many members of other teams were risk-averse on expanding into digital.

---

## Slide 5

Overall goals of our tactics: Improve ROAS, reallocate budget into areas with more room to scale

---

## Slide 6

Marketing history of the company

Evolution of measurement decisions

---

## Slide 7

1

2

3

4

---

## Slide 8

Prospecting: Display and social channels need reads longitudinally across campaign, audience and ad group levels.

Catalog: Need for improved and more frequent match-back incrementality for multiple unique segments and co-op audiences

Retargeting: Similar need for metrics on incrementality of each platform to adjust budget and find the right combination of vendors.

---

## Slide 9

December

February

March

May

Kick-off:  Critical step was getting the right people in the room – initial alignment on what would be considered

Data import and hygiene – I needed this step to take utmost precedence since multiple channels and systems involved

Set up of initial tests – Choice of first tests was important, as we needed a win to gain trust

First read out – We needed to explain the statistical rigor of the test approachably to executives

---

## Slide 10

---

## Slide 11

---

## Slide 12

Alignment: Executive trust was built through showing both successes and failures, consistent metrics, and a willingness to prove tactics before scaling

Analytics: It’s rare to have marketing and analytics deeply entwined, so cultivate those relationships early and often for a united front when making sweeping changes

Testing:  Starting with one channel first allowed us to create a value framework to triage where we needed the most immediate attention

## Slide 7

The 3 Disciplines model for Marketing Measurement teams

Ideal Measurement teams are cross-functional 

Start by organizing project teams along this structure, move to org structure changes later.

Insight

Build & vet models,  design tests, calculate counterfactuals. Provide statistical background for evidence presented, support decision makers with uncertainty quantification

## Slide 3

Module
An Introduction to Statistics 
for Media Experiments

## Slide 4

What To Expect Out Of This Course

Fundamental statistics for media experiments
Introduction to widely used nomenclatures, metrics/ terms used in media experiments
Introduction to how tests are conducted with real time data and how to interpret results
Overview of widely used methods

---

## Slide 5

What, How and Why of Media Experiments

What
A/B (aka split testing) 
Remove guess work 
Data driven decision
How
A/B (aka split testing) 
Remove guess work 
Data driven decision
Why
Causal and incremental impact of the interference (ad/campaign) in regards to true customer conversion and NOT what is reporter by CRM manager
Ad spends are now data driven
Remove guess work 
Data driven decision

---

## Slide 6

Agenda

Statistics Basics – Descriptive, Mean, Median, SD, Distributions
Hypothesis testing
Z interval, T interval, T-Test
Errors in HT
Geo tests
Methods to measure increment -Geo and Time based regression
Market selection algos – correlation, moving correlation, synthetic control methods, coarsened exact matching
Reference period selection – Visual, DTW
Counterfactual analysis

Geo tests  give analytics practitioners a strong foundation to then begin testing their assumptions on how factors such as location, demographics, proximity to stores or competitors affect sales, conversions, or customer engagement etc. (discussed further later)

---

## Slide 7

Hypothesis Testing

Hypothesis - Statement, that one needs to accept/reject
Example: Increasing the frequency of ads will increase the sales/reach
Ho: Treatment (ads) has no effect
H1: Treatment (ads) has effect

The process of accepting or rejecting the above statement from a statistics/data driven perspective is hypothesis testing

The point to note is, we will deal with a sample but are making a decision on the population

---

## Slide 8

Descriptive Statistics

---

## Slide 9

Mean, Median, Standard Deviation

Mean

Germ Free (control cohort)

Conventional Mice (BAU)

Standard Deviation

---

## Slide 10

Some Distributions

Gaussian, Normal

Binomial Normal
Central Limit theorem

Chi Square

t, student t distribution
Heavier tails

---

## Slide 11

Sample vs population

̅x vs μ, ̂p vs p
How confident are we to use the former to represent the latter..?
How close is the sample statistic to the population parameter? 

Solution:
An Interval (Cl: LB, UB) instead of point estimate
Each interval has a confidence coefficient (proportion): 1-α
Typical coefficients are 0.90, 0.95, 0.99 (90%, 95%, 99%)
Ex: One can be 95% confident that p falls between LB and UB

---

## Slide 12

Z interval

Cl for µ :

It is NOT that µ is within CL

It is, out of n samples, (1 - α)n times, the intervals contain the actual µ

https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat415/lesson/2/2.2

---

## Slide 13

T interval

σ  is to be known but we usually don’t know. Hence, it has to be approximated
 
After a little bit of work, proof

---

## Slide 14

t Test

Consider responses from control group and BAU
Determine:
If means are different(variances not known)
Case I and II (A/B test, Placebo-A/A test)
It is apparent in Case I that the means are different (SD is less)
Case II is not clear as the SD is large

Using t value and dof (n1+n2), one can find p from table
If p < α, Ho is rejected l statistical significance approach

---

## Slide 15

Errors in HT

https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/7402/how-do-i-find-the-probability-of-a-type-ii-error
https://towardsdatascience.com/probing-into-minimum-sample-size-formula-derivation-and-usage-8db9a556280b

---

## Slide 16

Characterizing the experiment: Minimum Detectable Effect (MDE)

Indicator of how sensitive an experiment is. How small of a change need to be detected. Thumbrule -5% relative difference

The relative minimum improvement over the baseline at certain degree of statistical significance

Example: 
Baseline conversion rate: 20%  
5% MDE: 19% < > 21%
 
Smaller the MDE, larger sample size and vice versa, for a given stat sig

Conceptually: 	
HT → Sample Size N →What is p value, power
Sample size calculation: p value, power is given    → Sample size N
			              		 Ex: p=0.05, power: 0.85

---

## Slide 17

Geo Test

Statistical significance limitations: 
Growing privacy restriction (user data)
No information on data variability

Alternate – Geo Test

Each area (geo) experimental unit
Serve ads specific to each geo and record the response metrics
User specific data (info/location) is NOT recorded
Geos: Zip codes, cities, Designated Market Areas (DMA)
Metrics: Sales, transactions, signups etc
Find ROAS and iROAS

---

## Slide 18

Methods to measure increment 1/2

Geo based regression

yt = α + βxt + εt

aggregate of conv during test period for a geo/ group

aggregate of conv during 
pretest period for a geo/ group

errors

Red  🡪 Control
Gray 🡪 Test

Relationship between pre-test and test period in control geo

Use same coeff to predict counterfactuals in test geo

---

## Slide 19

Methods to measure increment 2/2

Time  based regression

yt = α + βxt + εt

Treatment geo/group conversion

Control geo/group conversion

errors

Relationship between test geo and control geo

Use same coeff to predict counterfactuals in test geo

Red  → Control
Gray → Test

---

## Slide 20

Identifying test and control geos

---

## Slide 21

Market selection algorithms

Randomized experiments are the gold standard 
But important to create balanced groups of control and treatment 
small # geos 
heterogeneity of geos 
budget constraints 
choice of geo assignments (the business wants some geos to be present in the same group)

Solution: 
Stratification (based on the volume of response metrics)
Randomly assign control or treatment to every pair of adjacent geos.
Correlation or rolling correlation approaches

---

## Slide 22

Correlation and rolling correlation approaches

Correlation → pearson correlation. Global metric for a series. Compare two time series and bucket correlated time series (geos)








Rolling correlation → Correlation based on window size

---

## Slide 23

Advanced Algorithms 1/2: Synthetic control method

Randomized algorithms are not always possible
SCM → artificial unit that mimics the test unit
Based on the pre test data, SCMs find the combination of untreated units that most closely replicate the treatment geos 
Robust counterfactual for the effective measurement of incremental impact

Temporal variation in data instead of the cross-sectional one is used

https://towardsdatascience.com/understanding-synthetic-control-methods-dd9a291885a1

---

## Slide 24

Example
SCM example: Cigarette sales – predict something that is not known

---

## Slide 25

SCM example: Cigarette sales – predict something that is not known

https://towardsdatascience.com/causal-inference-with-synthetic-control-in-python-4a79ee636325

---

## Slide 26

Advanced Algorithms 2/2: Coarsened Exact Matching

Automated. Works well with large data sets

User matches the input attributes as much possible (Ex: Browser types, demographic factors) such that Control and test groups have close matches on the pretreatment covariates.

The outcomes have reduced model dependency, bias and heterogeneity

Series that has similar features (/attributes) are grouped into same bucket. More attributes matches attract larger weights. Strands with similar weights are in the same geo group.

The weights obtained from CEM are assigned to historical matched data and a weighted regression model is built for counterfactual estimation of test transactions.

---

## Slide 27

Advanced Algorithms 2/2: Coarsened Exact Matching

Automated. Works well with large data sets

User matches the input attributes as much possible (Ex: Browser types, demographic factors) such that Control and test groups have close matches on the pretreatment covariates.

The outcomes have reduced model dependency, bias and heterogeneity

Series that has similar features (/attributes) are grouped into same bucket. More attributes matches attract larger weights. Strands with similar weights are in the same geo group.

The weights obtained from CEM are assigned to historical matched data and a weighted regression model is built for counterfactual estimation of test transactions.

But how to identify pre test and test periods?

---

## Slide 28

Identifying reference periods

---

## Slide 29

Reference period selection within time strands

Trend : The long term pattern of a time series

Seasonality: Fluctuations around same month/week/ year

Cyclicity: Up and down movements due to business cycles

Random Variations: The unpredictable component

Additive model (less variance) or Multiplicative model (high variance)

https://quantdare.com/decomposition-to-improve-time-series-prediction/

---

## Slide 30

Advanced method -DTW

Align two sequence using a warping function, such that a pair of sequences have minimal distance 

Two equal or unequal lengths of time series 

It is a more intuitive compared to other distances such as euclidean or manhattan, because it matches similar shapes even if they are out of phase

---

## Slide 31

Analyzing Counterfactual Predictions

---

## Slide 32

Analyse the counterfactual predictions

Regression approaches such as GBR, TBR
Difference in Difference: Intra diff1 – Intra diff2

Test

http://cega.berkeley.edu/assets/cega_learning_materials/78/DnD_Quasi_Experimental_Methods_PBharadwaj_100324.pdf

Effect of campaign DiD (accounting for differences in the T&C and general time trend)

---

## Slide 33

Summary

Effect of campaign requires analyzing two time series models

Basic stat sig tests such as t-test were discussed along with limitations
Variance information, privacy restriction

Geo tests
GBR, TBR to measure increment 
Market selection algos for selecting test and control geos – Correlation, SCM, CEM
Reference period estimations – Visual, DTW

Counterfactual analysis – providing information on campaign effects

---

## Slide 34

Counterfactual Analysis Exercise

---

## Slide 35

Backup Slides

---

## Slide 36

ROAS and iROAS

Return on Ad Spends is the incremental impact caused by a particular ad spend 

It is a measure of the revenue which would not have been generated without the ad spend 

iROAS - incremental return on ad spends is further an useful measure for the evaluation of effectiveness of an intervention 

iROAS is the ratio of cumulative casual effect on a response metric to the cumulative causal effect on the marketing cost 

For a time t in the test period, iROAS(t) = Δresp(t) / Δcost(t)

Takeaway
ROAS is a cumulative statistic that calculates return based on total spending and total return why iROAS factors out the baseline level of profit to highlight the additional money generated from said investment

---

## Slide 37

Statistical Power and Precision of iROAS

The statistical power is the measure of probability of detecting an effect of a given magnitude or greater using a specific experimental design 
The precision can be defined as the half width of a 2-sided credible interval of the iROAS estimate 
CI half width is a concrete measure of efficiency of the experiment 
CI half width also indicates the smallest effect size which can be detected at a given statistical significance level 
Higher statistical power corresponds to higher precision
The common design factors which can influence the power and precision of an experiment are 
increase in ad spend by a factor of f reduces CI by a factor of 1/f
increase in pre test period length by n data points leads to reduction of CI by a factor of 1/√n
increase in test period length reduces CI as long as the intensity of ad change doesn’t change during the test period

---

Replacing Google PMAX 
with Google Standard Shopping

The test results came back with 94% incrementality, significantly higher than smart shopping (~60%), and what was expected internally, opening now the opportunity for continuous investment in Shopping tactics.
Pmax is paused and will be continuously evaluated as new features are added.

Market Insights

35% lift

---

## Slide 13

Before and After Results are a Game Changer

©

The client is a classic retailer, with very strong Q3 and Q4 performance. After making the changes to the marketing portfolio, performance skyrocketed, and the brand was able to spend even more during the quieter season, and increased revenue significantly, with improving efficiency at the same time. Revenue dropped only by 3.5% from Q4 2022 to Q1 2023 in the height of the recession!

Media Spend

+296k

+17%

Revenue

+9M

+65%

ROAS

+3.19

+41%

Orders

+23k

+34%

iCPO

-13%

iROAS

+166%

---

## Slide 14

Brand beats traditional seasonality patterns after committing to incrementality

©

Despite very challenging external factors like the current recession, inventory challenges, and change in customers spending patterns, the brand grew further in 2023. 

The only change made at the end of 2022/ beginning of 2023 was following solely the results from incrementality tests and execute accordingly. 

Google Shopping drove 35% of all incremental orders in Q1/ 2023.

---

## Slide 15

A Few Aspects to Keep in Mind

©

Pmax has great potential. To reach the customer at the right time, on the right platform (YouTube, Search, Display), with the right creative is a realistic promise. 

Rather sooner than later Google will provide enhancements to the product that makes it significantly better and very interesting for performance advertisers. It is important to keep an open dialogue and test regularly.

## Slide 11

Testing for Modeled Audiences

High

Modeled Audience

Platforms run look-alike algorithms based on data they collect about users on their platforms. They score users for each brand and aggregate users by score to create modeled audiences. Brands then setup campaigns to target these modeled audiences. These type of campaigns are typicalled called Conversion Optimized campaigns.
You can think of these audiences like a pyramid, with small number of high score audiences at the top, and large number of low score audiences at the bottom.

## Slide 44

Geo Match Market Simulation Analysis - Data Prep

Test Design

Objectives

Data Prep

Run Market selection program to recommend markets (Eg: Facebook Geolift)
Update the FeasibilityAnalysis-Market sheet with the markets for each cell
Sanity check the sheet

Is there enough lift to clear Minimum Detectable lift in each cell?
Can we afford the campaign?
Can we execute the campaign to design?

Simulate low-medium-high lifts, check the estimated iCPA and mCPA?
For a holdout test, would we continue to keep current levels of investment?
For a scale test, would we execute scaled investment?

---

## Slide 45

Geo Match Market Simulation Analysis - Data Prep

Test Design

Exclude the markets being in the Cells as geo exclusions on the BAU campaign
If there is a scale test, clone the campaign(s) that are being scaled, and add the markets being tested on as geo inclusions.

Flight the campaigns
Check the budgets
Check the end dates

Test Flight

For hold out tests, if you are testing a total black out for a channel, new campaigns being created have geo exclusions applied
For scale tests, keep an eye on the BAU campaign, to make sure the %scale desired is maintained.

---

## Slide 46

Geo Match Market Simulation Analysis - Data Prep

Test Design

Test Flight

Verify the actual delivery of campaigns compared to design. Did the campaigns over or under deliver?
Generate multiple lift estimates. Use FB Geo Lift, Google Causal Inference and Linear Models to estimate lift.

Calculate multipliers
If results are too strong or too weak, take estimate of lift from other upper funnel conversions. Triangulate the insights to see if they point to the same decision.

Go back to the decision matrix, and lookup the pre-defined decisions.

# M^2 Masterclass - Optimizing to Advanced Attribution metrics.pptx

# PowerPoint Presentation

## Slide 1

MASTERCLASS

Allie (Mottola) Lichtenberg  •  Educator

Measuring Marketing through Advanced Attribution

---

## Slide 2

I have been working with customers in optimization and analytics

Since 2013,

Senior Director of Customer Success at Measured

Sr. Director, Technical Account Management at DeepIntent

Allie Lichtenberg

Education
Bachelor of Arts in Biology, Chemistry & Studio Art from Manhattanville College
Masters of Business Administration from Iona University

Associate Account Director at Accordant Media

Director Data & Optimization at Hearst Magazines

Senior Director Data & Optimization at Hearst Magazines

Democratizing Marketing Measurement through M^2 as Educator

DEC 2020

FEB
2023

2023

APR
2022

2018

2018-2020

---

## Slide 3

Module
Optimizing to Advanced Attribution Metrics

---

## Slide 4

You’ve run your holdout tests or built your models, and have your advanced attribution multipliers calculated, so now what?

It’s time to optimize 
your media tactics

---

## Slide 5

3 Easy Steps

---

## Slide 6

Step 1: Translate multiplier into aaROAS

©

Step 2: Make budget decisions based on aaROAS

ROAS GOAL Self Attributed = $3.50; Advanced Attributed = $2.50

Notice how the decision could change when looking at advanced attributed ROAS

Key Learning

---

## Slide 7

Step 3:
Update budgets, ROAS/CPA goal, and optimizations  in each ad platform and optimize

---

## Slide 8

Optimize Facebook Prospecting

Self Attributed ROAS = $6.23; Advanced Attributed ROAS = $4.49;  Scale
There are two main ways to determine how much you can scale your FB campaign:
For larger budget increases, scale testing is a best practice
If increasing budget in smaller amounts (ex $5K-10K per day), you can make those small adjustments each day and monitor performance

---

## Slide 9

Optimize Facebook Prospecting

©

If Optimization Type is set to Value,  you continue to optimize to your platform goal of $3.50, knowing that is equivalent to your calculated advanced attribution goal


If your campaign objective is Reach or Brand Awareness, you can optimize delivery levers to achieve the same attributed ROAS goal:
Increase CPM
Make sure you’re seeing an increase in unique reach, otherwise you may just be paying more for the same audience, which typically doesn’t help performance

---

## Slide 10

2) Increase frequency
Track delivered frequency and calculate an optimal frequency
3) Broaden LAL targeting
Most platforms allow you to adjust LAL targeting in % increments; to increase scale, increase % targeted
4) Test new interest and psychographic segments  
Most platforms provide insight into converting audience make-up; you can use those insights to test similar/adjacent segments

Optimize Facebook Prospecting

---

## Slide 11

Optimize Search Non Brand

Self Attributed ROAS = $3.09; Advanced Attributed ROAS = $2.51;  Hold
Using a self attributed ROAS goal, would have led to a decision to reduce budget.  

It is often the case that brands who are heavily reliant on self-attributed metrics, are underfunding mid-upper funnel tactics like Search Non Brand. 
 
Over time, the underfunding tactics like Search Non Brand can lead to a decrease in new and unique customers and declining overall revenue.

Advanced attribution, typically allows for Search Non Brand to show better performance and therefore more opportunities for investment

Mid Funnel

---

## Slide 12

3) Test ad extensions (Ex. price)



4)Optimize landing pages

Step 3: Optimize Search Non Brand

In this example, aaROAS leads us to keep budget as is.  There is still room to optimize that budget so that it could potentially perform better over time, which could lead to a Fund decision.
Potential Optimizations:
Refine keyword list
You can use a variety of free tools to identify best and poor performing keywords (Google: https://support.google.com/google-ads/answer/7337243) 

Set maximum CPC target

---

## Slide 13

Final Thoughts - Success Starts at the Beginning

For best results, planning to measure advanced attribution should start before a campaign is set-up

Think about and plan for:

---

## Slide 14

Final Thoughts

For the data scientist and other attribution practitioners, it is helpful to remember that the results of the tests that you worked to design/interpret could lead to a significant restructuring of a brand’s marketing plan

For the brand marketer who will need to make budget decisions after receiving test results, it helps to make a decision matrix ahead of running tests to counterbalance emotions that arise from seeing unexpected/ disappointing results

For the media buyers and agency teams, remember that optimization best practices within each platform are the same whether using last-touch or advanced attribution, you’re simply looking to a new North Star

---

## Slide 3

The Brand: Jolyn

JOLYN is a designer, manufacturer and eCommerce retailer of women’s performance swimwear, athletic apparel and accessories.  Based in Orange County, the brand is inspired heavily by its Southern California roots. The result is a fun and distinct take on traditional swimwear that goes the distance sitting at the pinnacle of fashion and function.  

JOLYN sells primarily direct-to-consumer through its website and trunk shows hosted by brand reps.  The company's in-house and rep teams are comprised of highly decorated athletes: swimmers, divers, lifeguards, surfers, water polo players, runners and more that played at the collegiate, professional and Olympic levels.

## Slide 9

We are a ~10 year old brand. One of my primary challenges is, a lot of my revenue seems to come from organic sources. Which makes sense, we have a lot of brand love, our customers post and share about the brand just like that. But how do I grow the brand if all my sales are really driven by organic sources?

Hmmm… wonder how much of her business is New vs Returning customers. If it's such a beloved brand, she must have strong retention rates, and a good chunk of her revenue must be returning customers

Step 1: Conversion Types: New vs Returning analyses
Step 2: MMMs for each convtype for understanding contribution of media vs organic sources

Solution Architecture

Translating Business Questions to Analytical Problem Statements

---

## Slide 10

Translating Business Questions to Analytical Problem Statements

It’s so overwhelming to understand whether Facebook is driving real growth for the brand. My Google analytics reports a Facebook ROAS of 0.5 and Facebook itself reports 2.5. It’s so challenging to navigate these numbers to manage spend, let alone explain it to my CFO.

This is very typical situation for most marketers. She needs clean multipliers.

Step 3: Triangulation Analysis and Multipliers

Solution Architecture

---

## Slide 11

Translating Business Questions to Analytical Problem Statements

Our board is constantly asking us for our LTV:CAC ratio, and we get lost chasing data issues. We are trying to understand our true unit economics so we can drive profitable growth, but navigating the data is a challenge.

There are probably some data hygiene things to work through. But we need to overlay LTVs to get to unit economics.

Step 4: LTV Analysis
Step 5:
Flywheel analysis: Overlay other costs and get to unit economics

Solution Architecture

---

## Slide 12

Translating Business Questions to Analytical Problem Statements

…and then there we have two very different customers, the training customer and the surf customer, it's not easy to get to. The definitions are pretty nuances, but it's there, and we theorize that it could have a real implication to our unit economics.

Hmmm… wonder how different the retention rates and LTVs are for those two segments.

Step 5: Breaking down LTV by customer segment 
Step 6+:
MMMs by Customer Segment, Triangulation Analysis, Multipliers

Solution Architecture

---

## Slide 13

Solution Strategy: Marketing Accounting Framework => Conversion Types

---

## Slide 14

Conversion Types: Breaking down the business into its constituent parts

As part of solution strategy, we apply Marketing Accounting Framework principles to break down the business into its meaningfully constituent parts

Roughly half the revenue is from New customers and half is from Returning customers.

We are expecting to see media have more impact in driving New customers and less impact on Returning customers

Assumption

New vs Returning Customer Revenue

---

## Slide 15

Solution Strategy: Role of MMMs

---

## Slide 16

Solution Strategy: Building MMMs to decompose credit to various business drivers

Process

---

## Slide 17

Interpretation: MMMs report card the drivers behind New Customer Acquisition

About 40% is driven by media and promos/discounts

About 40% of new customer acquisition is Base

About 20% is momentum

---

## Slide 18

Interpretation: MMMs report card the drivers behind Returning Customer Orders

A good 40% of returning revenue is being driven by media meant for new customer acquisition
~20% is discounts; customers are responding strongly to promo

About 40% of the business is baseline

Seasonality has a negative impact indicating some need for unpacking

---

## Slide 19

Solution Strategy: Role of MMMs

---

## Slide 20

Interpretation: MMMs decomposition to Multipliers and Channel ROIs

---

## Slide 21

The Next Problem Statement

Well, how does that all that translate to unit economics for the business? We are not an early venture backed grow-at-all-costs business. We are a bottom-line-conscious-return-strong-EBIT-to get-everyone-paid type of business. How does this translate to LTV:CAC ratio?

---

## Slide 22

Solution Strategy: Overlay LTV

---

## Slide 23

Solution Strategy: Removing noise in LTV reporting

Resellers who buy locally and resell in Asia add noise and skew to LTV estimates

---

## Slide 24

Retention rates are strong, and LTV is stable YoY

With all the reseller noise, we couldn't be sure about our LTV, but this LTV cut now finally gives us crisp understanding of longitudinal customer behaviors. We now understand our LTV and customer maturity much better

Over 24 months, about 35% of customers come back. Average LTV is around $150, and is pretty stable for the last 2-3 years

---

## Slide 25

LTV/CAC is strong

LTV/aaCAC 
4.6

Finally, I am able to get a credible LTV:CAC ratio to report back to the board. Hopefully, we can buy the operating team some room to execute with this strong read.

LTV  = $150 
aaCAC  =   $32

---

## Slide 26

Solution Strategy: Cost accounting to get to unit economics

---

## Slide 27

Putting it all together to get to the Unit Economics of the business

Having these big picture KPIs, gave me the conviction to step away from data that was bogging me down. Now I can make decisions in a timely manner with confidence and clarity.

Jolyn makes $37 in contribution margin with the first order. Usually, this number is negative for many emerging brands.

And the brand makes $63 over the next 24 months, in all making it $100 in contribution per customer.

With these unit economics, now the board will want to see us invest aggressively into growth. So, Jen just needs to give me a number!

---

## Slide 28

Well wait, where am going to find that kind of growth. I am already a beloved brand among folks who are training, how much growth is there to be had?

New Problem Statement

---

## Slide 29

Solution Strategy: Starting the next Advanced Attribution evolution

---

## Slide 30

Unpacking LTV by customer segments

For families who have kids in swim training, we probably are very well penetrated. I wouldn’t be surprised if we have some 30-40% of TAM in the training segment. Surf is the big opportunity for us, but it’s a different GTM entirely, it's more seasonal, weaker unit economics. My challenge now is to shape an efficient GTM for the surf segment

Training is almost 85% of the business, Surf is a smaller 15%

---

## Slide 31

You’ll learn something in each step that’ll shape the next steps you take

Advanced Attribution is a 
Journey

## Slide 13

Average service value: new patients by channel

There isn’t significant distinction in new patient average service value among marketing channels - with the exception of Direct Mail which has an average service value almost $70 higher than the average of all other channels. ## Slide 15

Media drives both new patient and existing patient appointment booking.

## Slide 16

MMM result summary - new patient appointments booked

Insights:

While only 5% of spend, Direct Mail had the 3rd highest incremental contribution % (0.7%) and the lowest CPA ($210) by a significant margin.
Search: Non-brand has 2x the incremental contribution of any channel but still at a very high CPA of $731. Brand search has the lowest incremental contribution of any marketing channel and the highest CPA indicating it is not capturing new patient demand.

Media drives around 4.2% of new patient appointment bookings.

‹#›

---

## Slide 17

MMM result summary - existing patient appointments booked

Insight:

Different from new patients,  Brand search has the 3rd highest spend % and 3rd highest contribution % but the 2nd lowest CPA indicating existing patients use brand search “navigationally” to find JDC to schedule. Lower CPA attributable to lower CPC for brand terms.
Also, unlike with new patients, Direct Mail seems to be less effective at driving repeat booking - though spend levels are low it has the highest CPA at $140.

Media drives around 5.6% of existing patient appointment bookings.

‹#›

---

## Slide 18

MMM result summary - new patient appointments completed

Insight:

Brand search has the 2nd lowest  contribution at 0.7% and the highest CPA further evidencing that it does not drive incremental new patient appointment completes. Unlike with new patients, Direct Mail seems to be less effective at driving repeat booking - though spend levels are low it has the highest CPA at $140.

Media drives around 5.3% of existing patient completed appointments.

‹#›

---

## Slide 19

MMM result summary - existing patient appointments completed

Insight:

Non-brand search represents over half spend but only 28% of incremental contribution.

Media drives around 4.1% of existing patient completed appointments.

‹#›

---

## Slide 20

GA and ad platform tracking overstate digital media contribution to appointments booked.

‹#›

---

## Slide 21

New patient booked ROAS: GA vs. MMM attribution

GA attribution over credits all channels with the largest variance in Brand Search. This is not uncommon as brand search tends to be one of the least incremental channels.

‹#›

---

## Slide 28

## Slide 29

©

Conclusion

What? Incrementality flywheel analysis provides a guideline to assess if (and how much) room there is scale or cut spend by connecting the dots between marketing and financial impact

Now What? Use analysis results alongside channel performance and causal testing to support channel-level investment decisions

---

## Slide 6

Thinking of business outcomes as P&Ls

2 P&L: New Customers, Active Customers
Many emerging brands in eCommerce may have two broad marketing executions targeting new customer acquisition and retention marketing to their house file. Marketing reporting would need to be broken up into two P&Ls, targeting the two executions.

3 P&L: New Customers, Active Customers, Churned Customers
Mature brands tend to have a 3rd distinct customer segments, churned customers, and many times a large portion of the customer file may represent prior customers. They tend have a developed reactivation strategy for marketing to churned customers. Marketing reporting would need to be broken up into three P&Ls, targeting the three executions..

1 P&L: New Customers
Businesses like Wedding Rings, Insurance Lead generation mostly have one-time transactions with customers they acquire. Marketing reporting can be simplified to be just one customer segment, or a single P&L.

title: LaserAwayFrom Audit to Action.pptx
markdown:
# LaserAwayFrom Audit to Action.pptx

# PowerPoint Presentation

## Slide 1

Paul Baumgarthuber   •  CMO, LaserAway

From Audit to Action:Unlocking Incremental Growth Through Advanced Measurement at LaserAway

---

## Slide 2

Introduction: My Journey at LaserAway

---

## Slide 3

The Challenges I Faced as CMO

When I joined LaserAway 11 years ago, I was excited about the opportunity to lead marketing for a fast-growing aesthetic dermatology company with multiple locations. But I quickly realized that while the brand had tremendous potential, there were significant hurdles to overcome:
Fragmented Tech Stack:
We had multiple tools and platforms that didn’t talk to each other, creating silos and inefficiencies
Poor Data Quality:
Inconsistent data collection across locations made it hard to trust the numbers.
Misaligned Attribution:
We were relying on last-click attribution, which undervalued our upper- and mid-funnel efforts like social media and overemphasized bottom-funnel channels like search

---

## Slide 4

Why We Focused on Tech Stack Audits and Advanced Measurement

Time and Resource Constraints:
Given our limited time today, I had to narrow our focus. While customer experience, site layout, brand/creative, and in-location operations are all essential components of a successful strategy, I’ve learned that without a strong tech and data foundation, none of those efforts can reach their full potential.
The Need for Scalability:
With multiple locations and ambitious growth goals, we required a tech ecosystem that could seamlessly grow alongside our business
The Desire for Data-Driven Decisions:
Moving beyond gut instincts to build a culture rooted in actionable insights and informed decision-making

---

## Slide 5

Part 1: Auditing the Tech Stack and Data Quality

---

## Slide 6

The State of Our Tech Stack When I Joined

Inventory of Tools:
We had a CRM, a POS system, email marketing tools, social media platforms, and web analytics—but they weren’t all integrated.
Data Collection Challenges:
Data was scattered across systems, and there was no single source of truth.
Data Quality Issues:
Incomplete, inconsistent, and outdated data made it hard to trust our metrics.

---

## Slide 7

Our Tech Stack Audit Checklist

Inventory of Tools and Platforms:
We cataloged every tool and identified overlaps and gaps
Data Collection and Storage:
We centralized data in a cloud-based data warehouse
Data Quality Assessment:
We cleaned up our data, ensuring accuracy, completeness, consistency, and timeliness
Integration and Automation:
We used APIs and middleware to connect our systems and automate workflows
Scalability:
We chose tools that could grow with us, adding new locations and channels without breaking the system
User Adoption and Training:
We trained our teams to use the tools effectively and established feedback loops for continuous improvement

---

## Slide 8

Best Practices We Learned

---

## Slide 9

Part 2: Advanced Measurement Techniques

---

## Slide 10

The Problem with Last-Click Attribution

When I joined, we were heavily reliant on last-click attribution (and still are to a certain extent). This meant:
Overvaluing Search: Bottom-funnel channels like search got all the credit.
Undervaluing Social Media: Upper- and mid-funnel efforts like social media and display ads were seen as “nice to have” but not essential.
Misaligned Budgets: We were pouring money into channels that captured demand but weren’t driving incremental growth.

---

## Slide 11

How We Implemented Triangulation Analysis

Triangulation Tool

Platform Reported Performance

Lead Form Submissions & Lead revenue

Findings

Insights

Data Collection

---

## Slide 12

Leveraging MMM to Quantify Incremental Impact

Model Development:
We analyzed historical data on marketing spend, sales, leads and external factors (e.g., seasonality).
Results:

---

## Slide 13

Best Practices We Followed

Combine Data Sources: Use platform-reported, CRM, and web analytics data
Focus on Incrementality: Understand the true impact of each channel
Iterate and Refine: Continuously update your models with new data
Communicate Clearly: Present insights in a way that stakeholders can understand and act on

---

## Slide 14

Part 3: LaserAway Case Study on Advanced Measurement

---

## Slide 15

The Challenge: Misaligned Attribution

When I joined LaserAway, one of the biggest challenges was understanding the true impact of our marketing efforts. We were heavily reliant on last-click attribution, which meant:
Overvaluing Search: Bottom-funnel channels like search got all the credit
Undervaluing Social Media, CTV and Streaming Audio: Upper- and mid-funnel efforts like social media and CTV were seen as “nice to have” but not essential
Misaligned Budgets: We were pouring money into channels that captured demand but weren’t driving incremental growth

---

## Slide 16

The Solution: Marketing Mix Modeling (MMM)

Model Development:
We analyzed historical data on marketing spend, sales, and external factors (e.g., seasonality)
Results:

---

## Slide 17

MMM: Reallocation by Channels, Scenario 1

Media Mix:

Scenario #1 keeps budget flat across highest spend channels, cuts or scales back underperformers while scaling back Bing and Streaming. 
$8.2M incremental annual CM

---

## Slide 18

MMM: Reallocation by Channels, Scenario 2

Scenario #2 layers on higher investment levels in Bing and Streaming based on scale potential. 
$10M incremental annual spend would result in $22.4M incremental annual CM.

Media Mix:

---

## Slide 19

The Impact of Our Changes

Improved Efficiency:
Our integrated tech stack and clean data saved time and reduced errors.
Better Budget Allocation:
By understanding the incremental impact of each channel, we can optimize our spend.
Increased Conversions:
Our reallocated budget should drive an incremental revenue of X

---

## Slide 20

Conclusion: My Call to Action

Recap Key Points
As CMO of LaserAway, I faced challenges with a fragmented tech stack, poor data quality, and misaligned attribution
By focusing on tech stack audits and advanced measurement, we built a strong foundation and optimized our marketing spend
Expected results: improved efficiency, better budget allocation, and increased conversions


Your Next Steps
Audit Your Tech Stack:
Identify gaps and inefficiencies in your current setup
Invest in Advanced Measurement:
Use triangulation and MMM to uncover the true impact of your marketing efforts
Drive Incremental Growth:
Allocate budget based on incremental impact, not just direct conversions

---

## Slide 21

Q & A

Modeled Audience

Platforms run look-alike algorithms based on data they collect about users on their platforms. They score users for each brand and aggregate users by score to create modeled audiences. Brands then setup campaigns to target these modeled audiences. These type of campaigns are typicalled called Conversion Optimized campaigns.
You can think of these audiences like a pyramid, with small number of high score audiences at the top, and large number of low score audiences at the bottom.

(not set) is losing almost all its last click credit

## Slide 47

Benefits of using a Post Purchase Survey (PPS)

“How did you hear about us?”
What really matters is why someone purchased and what they remember
A customers first touchpoint (Channel Attributed) could be something they don’t even remember

Market Insight

---

## Slide 48

Using a PPS to compare Facebook and TikTok

To calculate implied revenue:
Download PPS data in an excel spreadsheet and sum up the revenue for responses of Facebook and TikTok
I have a different response for Facebook and Instagram, so for Facebook I add those together
Now that we have the total PPS Revenue, divide that by the response rate to get an “implied revenue”
Divide that “implied revenue” by ad spend to get an “implied ROAS”

---

## Slide 49

Specific Calculations to find Implied ROAS

Given Data:

Revenue for responses:
Facebook = $34.6k
Instagram = $39.6k 
TikTok = $16.7k

Response rate = 41.68%

Facebook Spend = $154k

TikTok Spend = $37.7k

Facebook Calculations:

Implied Revenue =
($34.6 + $39.6) / 0.4168 = $178k

Implied ROAS = 
$178k / $154k = 1.16

TikTok Calculations:

Implied Revenue =
$16.7k / 0.4168 = $40k

Implied ROAS = 
$40k / $37.7k = 1.06

---

## Slide 50

Leverage PPS Implied ROAS to create an %Multiplier

% Multiplier = PPS Implied Revenue / Channel Reported Revenue

These results allow us to translate in platform ROAS to a comparable metric and vice versa

---

## Slide 51

Normalizing ROAS Data

FB AA ROAS = 1.67 x 0.69 = 1.15


TT AA ROAS = 1.35 x 0.78 = 1.05 (rounding errors lol!)

---

## Slide 52

Actionable Scenario, weekly read

Budgets - 20k/day on FB, 2k/day on TikTok

Originally invented to serve CPG marketers, got adopted more broadly in the last 20 years.

With the advent of the internet and profilteration of websites, LastTouch attribution was born primarily out of technical convenience.

With rising Display media investment, and frequency with consumers growing, multi-touch attribution approaches came to market as an improvement over LastAd, to help justify display’s role in the funnel.

Rise of walled gardens, consumer privacy legislation and death of cookie, leads to experimentation-based methods for media measurement.

Democratization of MMM sciences, easy access to data science talent and renewed focus on 1st party data gives rise to a flood of MMM tools and services.

24 | Key Takeaways | Insights | Recommendations | |---|---|---| | Zip test - activating in Opportunity zips in Virginia generated impressive lift | - Opportunity zips outshone Strong zips in performance by a country mile.
- When we activated in the opportunity zips, the nearby zips from other states/zip labels were seeing more sales. This may be because
     - People travelled between zips for various reasons like work, college etc
     - Their address was different from their temporary residence
     - Nearest store was in a VA location
- As expected, Opportunity zips, even outside test regions were seeing elevated performance in comparison to strong zips, which further validates our underlying statistical selection methods and supports an expanded scale test | - A scaled test for zip-level activation covering 1/4th to 1/3rd of the country
     - See if we can replicate a similar effect with larger test group. | | - Opportunity & regular zips combined give a strong 22% to 33% lift on revenue
- At a ROAS range of 6-8, which will put this execution among the most efficient tactics in Laseraway’s portfolio | | | [Confluence Link](#) --- ## Streaming Channels Scale Geo Test | Feb’ 24 | Key Takeaways | Insights | Recommendations | |------------------------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | Scaling spend in streaming channels in about half the country generated strong lead revenue lift | - We are able to measure an average lift of ~12% - OTT (Roku, Yelp-TTD) and Audio (Pandora) streaming channels have strong lead generation under scaled spend. | Change the national media mix to incorporate the results in the test cell. Rebalance portfolio spend from Search into Streaming. | | The Non-Brand Search scale down has been executed to have minimal impact on lead revenue | - Scale down in Non Brand Search is having minimal effects of revenue - Non-Brand Search spend was cut by ~47%, that represented ~18.2% of total monthly spend. - We are estimating that ~16% of attributable revenue was lost due to the cuts, which represents ~4.5% of total lead revenue | | [Confluence Link](#) --- ## National Scale Zip level Test Design | Mar’ 24 **Recommendation** Run a scaled test for Tiers 1 and 2 with a total budget of $420,920. | Tier | Predicted Orders Per Capita | Population | Estimated Lift | Budget | Estimated ROAS | |------|-----------------------------|------------|----------------|----------|----------------| | 1 | > 1 and <= 25 | 1,965,419 | 37% | $123,821 | $1.4 | | 2 | >0.5 to <=1 | 4,715,856 | 38% | $297,099 | $0.6 | | 3 | <=0.5 | 15,722,889 | 67% | $990,542 | $0.3 | [Confluence Link](#) --- ## Geospatial Analysis | Jun’ 24 **Recommended Approach** Utilize regional thresholds for distance-based targeting. For example, California with a 54-mile threshold due to extended commutes and community metrics. This approach ensures high efficiency by focusing on zip codes with more than 10 customers within the regionally adjusted boundaries. **Summary** Geographic distribution of customers is not always oriented in a consistent distance from store locations. Effective targeting combining historical zip level sales data and geospatial analysis techniques can help in optimizing advertising spend and maximizing sales potential.
